text:
What examples do we have of things being similar in probably to a UUID collision?
I assume a UUID collision is much much more likely than pair production generating a cat and anti-cat pair from a nuclear explosion for example.
So that is too unlikely.
On the other hand winning lotto is far too likely

elements.text:
What examples do we have of things being similar in probably to a UUID collision?
I assume a UUID collision is much much more likely than pair production generating a cat and anti-cat pair from a nuclear explosion for example.
So that is too unlikely.
On the other hand winning lotto is far too likely

text: the collision chance is about 1 in 2^60

text:
Grains of sand on earth is about 2^63.
So something like "imagine there are 10 grains of sand on earth that are special. UUID clash is the same as picking one of those up by chance"

text: Winning the lottery 3 times in a row is as probable as UUID collision?? :open_mouth: Hmm I guess I imagined UUID collisions to be much rarer than they actual are. Or maybe underestimated the winning the lottery? Chance is hard to visualize

elements.text: Winning the lottery 3 times in a row is as probable as UUID collision??
Hmm I guess I imagined UUID collisions to be much rarer than they actual are. Or maybe underestimated the winning the lottery? Chance is hard to visualize

text:
Winning the lottery is improbable, but not unimaginable. Where it gets unimaginable is that the probability of winning it twice in a row is the probability of winning it once, squared. Three times in a row is the cube of winning it once. 

Taking powers of small numbers makes VERY small numbers very fast

elements.text:
Winning the lottery is improbable, but not unimaginable. Where it gets unimaginable is that the probability of winning it twice in a row is the probability of winning it once, squared. Three times in a row is the cube of winning it once. 

Taking powers of small numbers makes VERY small numbers very fast

text: Yes good point! I think that is what is making it even much harder to visualize for me. Doing things in a row (squaring, cubing, powers) of already really improbable events make it even much much smaller/even more improbable.

elements.text: Yes good point! I think that is what is making it even much harder to visualize for me. Doing things in a row (squaring, cubing, powers) of already really improbable events make it even much much smaller/even more improbable.

text: In practice though, couldn't the same uuid be generated if a user somehow manages to create two uuids with a faulty source of entropy for the random number generator. Or of course any other nonanticipated weirdness, like someone deliberately choosing only 8's for their uuid :thinking_face:

elements.text: In practice though, couldn't the same uuid be generated if a user somehow manages to create two uuids with a faulty source of entropy for the random number generator. Or of course any other nonanticipated weirdness, like someone deliberately choosing only 8's for their uuid
